bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas writes about his reconciliation with Magoon, remarking that Magoon will probably recommend him as his successor in Panama. He also comments on the state of disease in Panama, noting that pneumonia remains primary problem.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1906

opener.dateline:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
____
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
August 4th 1906.

div1.p:
I have time to write only
a few lines to catch next steamer,
Magoon & I have been gradually
getting closer together till I think
our differences are about settled.
He expects promotion & to leave here
immediately after Mr. Pools visit
& has just told me that he has
recommended that I be appointed
Governor to succeed him.

So my conscience smiles
me & I want to ask Gen. O Reilly
to destroy my letter & consider any
mean things about Magoon un-
said and not to mention to the
2
Secretary any grievances I had.
Of course any assistance Gen. O Reil
ly can give the good cause will be
thankfully received.

We all join in congratulation
to the Office for the successful
issue they have brought to our bill
As I understand it every body
is committed to its passage need-
session. The youngsters are de-
lighted.

All well, We have about gotten
rid of tropical diseases, but
pneumonia is playing hot with
our negro laborers.
